data.title: Terminal quick picker doesn't have a registered context key
data.body: Needs one for some keybindings

data.title: Incorrect comment string
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: 10.12.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open this file in vscode: https://github.com/mozilla-mobile/firefox-ios/blob/master/Telemetry/Events.swift#L3
2. You will find that the whole file is a comment string.

The reason is line 3 has such characters: `//` in the url, and the comment string terminate character `*/`  is at the end of the line.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

![dfemmgpuaaapm38](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8279858/28395461-d973bd5a-6d26-11e7-9b04-69377f44566e.jpg)

data.title: Folder Settings could just open workspace settings in no-MRU workspace
data.body:
testing https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30722

insiders 1.15.0 9a308d11

in a non-multi-root workspace instance, opening the command palette and choosing "Preferences: Open Folder Settings" results in an info message:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1487073/28394618-3872cc3a-6ca3-11e7-8953-2704b042e3cd.png)

In a multi-root workspace, this opens the settings for the folder.

Is there a reason we don't simply open the workspace settings in the non-MRW scenario?  It would be one less message for the user.

data.title: javascript.format.insertSpaceBeforeFunctionParenthesis setting being ignored
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: MacOS Sierra 10.12.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set "javascript.format.insertSpaceBeforeFunctionParenthesis" to false in User settings.
2. Type in any function like `var blabla = function();`
3. VS Code automatically inserts a space before the function parenthesis. 

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes.

data.title: Duplicate folders in .code-workspace
data.body:
testing https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30722

Insiders 1.15.0
9a308d11

Loading of folders stops if a folder is repeated in the .code-workspace file. admittedly a poorly formed file :) 

loading `foo.code-workspace`

``` json
{
	"id": "1500494428473",
	"folders": [
		"file:///Users/chris/src/vscode-mongodb",
		"file:///Users/chris/src/vscode-docker",
		"file:///Users/chris/src/vscode-docker",
		"file:///Users/chris/src/vscode-azurelogin",
		"file:///Users/chris/src/vscode-azureappservice",
		"file:///Users/chris/src/vscode-extension-samples"
	]
}
```

results in only the vscode-mongodb and vscode-docker folders being loaded.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1487073/28393376-33d3fe40-6c9b-11e7-9404-e146bd7a6942.png)

i would expect it to keep on loading the rest of the folders in this case since the vscode-docker folder is valid, you just don't have to load it 2x.

data.title: MRW: Cannot debug any folder except first
data.body:
testing https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30722, specifically "debugging (node.js and extension host debugging) work as before".

Insiders 1.15.0 9a308d11

I've created a workspace with all of my extensions and the idea is that I could do a lot of copy/paste between folders and then run/debug any of the individual extensions.  

However, it appears I can only debug the first folder of my multi-root workspace, there is no way for me to pick which one I wish to launch.

On backlog?

data.title: Allow to drag/drop folder onto multi-root workspace to add folder
data.body:
testing https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30722

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1487073/28392903-f66c9758-6c98-11e7-9019-a3f9eed5fe2f.png)

Drag and drop of a folder onto an instance of VS Code that has multiple roots does not add the folder to the workspace. Instead, it reloads the workbench on the single folder.

data.title: What happened to highlight all occurrences with cursor?
data.body: Used to be able to place the cursor on a word and it would highlight all occurrences in gray, both in the document and in the scroll bar. This seems to be gone. Also when I hover over a word, the word "any" shows up in a tooltip. What is this for?

data.title: New Workspace - add a folder or write a file?
data.body:
Testing https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30722

Version:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1487073/28392741-1845e196-6c98-11e7-842b-8d3463eddfab.png)

"Save Workspace" prompts me to save a file on disk, "Open Workspace" prompts me for a file on disk, but "New Workspace" prompts me to open a folder(s). 

I would expect the same file prompt behavior for New Workspace, where I give the workspace a name and location on disk, VS Code is reloaded, and then I Add Folder to Workspace to begin to populate it.

data.title: VSIX: Right click -> Install

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
It happens fairly frequently to package an extension and install it while developing them. 

Right now we have to do this:
- Open the command palette
- Run `Extensions: Install from VSIX...`
- Locate the right folder
- Select the *.vsix file

I think this can be shortened quite a bit by adding an `Install` option when right clicking *.vsix files from the tree view.

What do you think?

data.title: Support large documents in extension host
Regex Find works differently than Find in Files
data.body:
The **Find** command, with regex turned on, seems to be implemented with a different flavor of regex than the **Find in Files** command. The latter returns errors when not escaping braces, while the former does not.

- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.1 (2648980a697a4c8fb5777dcfb2ab110cec8a2f58, 2017-07-13T19:08:57.197Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
dart-code|Dan|2.1.0
xml|Dot|1.9.2
vscode-docker|Pet|0.0.16
Bookmarks|ale|0.15.2
thrift|cdu|0.0.1
vscode-yaml-validation|dja|0.0.1
python|don|0.6.7
Go|luk|0.6.62
vscode-apache|mrm|1.1.1
sublime-keybindings|ms-|2.9.1
java|red|0.7.0
gitblame|wad|1.11.3

(2 theme extensions excluded)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a document with `foo{}` in it.
2. Initiate the **Find** command, turn on Regex
3. Type `foo{}` in the Find field. You should get a match.
4. Try **Find in Files**, with the same search.
5. This results in a parse error, shown below.
6. A character group results in a different error  see the 2nd screenshot below.
7. Add a backslash before brackets  `foo\{\}`  and the searches now work.

![screen shot 2017-07-19 at 2 19 45 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7768348/28390102-86f7fe54-6c8d-11e7-94a1-dbdf51b2ff03.png)

![screen shot 2017-07-19 at 2 20 57 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7768348/28390106-8fe895d2-6c8d-11e7-97e2-9a02280caa40.png)

Reproduces without extensions: **Yes**

data.title: Lose config almost on every upgrade
data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: mac os el capitan

I lose my configuration on almost every upgrade of VS Code to the next version ever since some time in the spring. I have seen a similar issue #21676 but is seems to be resolved there. 

In my case, the whole /User folder gets deleted inside `~/Library/Application\ Support/Code`, what could cause this? Could it be that I've setup locale inside VS Code different from default on my laptop? 

I thought it stopped for me recently, however, it has just happened again with upgrade to 1.14.1. I have cleared caches right before upgrading, though, by removing all folders from `~/Library/Caches/`.

VS Code is an awesome product, but this issue is a stopper for me

data.title: Need a way for extensions to disable textmate quickSuggestions during textDocument/completion
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: All

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Enable quickSuggestions and wordBasedSuggestions.
2. Type some C++ code like "#pragma o<Enter>".

Bug: The "o" on Enter will get autocompleted undesirably and there's no way for the language extension to disable the wordBasedSuggestion. VS Code has the comments and strings settings, but it doesn't allow extensions to have it's own classification to disable quickSuggestions (i.e. if the extension knows the code is like a comment/etc. and shouldn't autocomplete).

Reproduces without extensions: No

data.title: Launch VSCODE Application in WSL without XServer
data.body:
I have installed windows 10 (b.1703) creators update recently and I am using ubuntu subsystem(WSL).There I have installed Visual Studio Code successfully(Node.js everything installed).

I followed this link too - [support](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/setup/linux)

Problem is that any GUI elements required application can be launch but not working(no GUI will be elements displayed reason may be WSL has no direct Graphic driver support).

![VSCOE Launch](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3683121/28388703-38ee16e4-6cf1-11e7-95ae-15afa1362140.PNG)

As image shown above.after I command to execute vscode thorough 

> macxfadz@BC-LPTP:~$ code

 the WSL BASH take few seconds and nothing display during that time and print second line with empty respond.

I wanted to know How to provide graphic driver support to WSL in order to facilitate GUI applications(in this case VSCODE)? without installing 3rd party software such as XMing-Xserver,putty etc.

Else do we have any other mechanism to achieve it ? only modifying Ubuntu(Linux subsystem) side? other than switching to Windows 10 Insider preview builds?

**Please note that** I don't want to launch VSCODE installed in windows 10 launch via WSL ubuntu bash.

data.title: Automatically add dnf repository on .rpm install
data.body:
I recently installed the Skype for Linux .rpm via dnf - doing so added a skype-stable yum repository automatically. I could then agree to key signing upon the next dnf upgrade. 

I thought that this might be an idea for future releases of the VSC .rpm, rather than having to add it manually.

data.title: VSCode Hangs on breakpoint when attached to remote debugger on a windows docker container
data.body:
When attaching the VSDB.exe vs code clr remote debugger to a dotnet running process in a windows docker container in VSCode, the applications goes into debug mode and retrieves a list of threads and shows the debug output, but when I hit a breakpoint, VS Code hangs and stopping debugging shuts down the docker container. Using the same debugger works fine locally. Is this a problem in Docker or VSCode?

Docker info
```

Storage Driver: windowsfilter
 Windows:
Logging Driver: json-file
Plugins:
 Volume: local
 Network: l2bridge l2tunnel nat null overlay transparent

Registry: https://index.docker.io/v1/
Experimental: true
Insecure Registries:
 127.0.0.0/8
Live Restore Enabled: false
```

I've included debugger output logs from local debug and remote debug below

Dockerfile
```
 FROM microsoft/nanoserver
```

Remote debug task

data.title: vscode calls `git status` when in background, which can cause other git usages to fail
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.1 (2648980a697a4c8fb5777dcfb2ab110cec8a2f58, 2017-07-13T19:08:57.197Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.5.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
you-complete-me|Ric|1.0.36
project-manager|ale|0.18.1
githistory|don|0.2.1
python|don|0.6.7
gitlens|eam|4.3.1
vscode-great-icons|emm|2.1.11
cpptools|ms-|0.11.4
rewrap|stk|1.4.1
better-align|wwm|1.1.6



---

This is a new issue to track the discussion starting at this point on an old issue starting here:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/901#issuecomment-309294814

@fredizzimo @alexjeffburke @benesch have all recently reported the same problem.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open vscode to a git project
2. switch away from vscode to a terminal
3. touch a file in in git project
4. observe the blue "clock" on top of the version control icon flashes in vscode
5. occasionally, trying to do a rebase in the terminal window with vscode open in the background will fail with `fatal: Unable to create '.git/index.lock': File exists`

You can avoid the problem with `"git.autorefresh": false`, but it's sad to have to lose all the functionality just to avoid this problem.  I posit that the protections against background `git status` calls added in faeb58e were lost when the git code was refactored into an extension.

I've gone so far as to run this in the background, but it's a bit convoluted to expect people to do that.
```
#!/usr/bin/env osascript -l JavaScript

function run(argv) {
    var app = Application.currentApplication()
    app.includeStandardAdditions = true

    vscode = Application('Electron')
    // add git.autorefresh to user config file if it isn't already there
    app.doShellScript('grep -q git.autorefresh ~/Library/Application\\ Support/Code/User/settings.json || ' +
                      'perl -i -0pe \'s%(.*)}(.*)%$1\\n    //updated by external script\\n    , "git.autorefresh": true\\n}$2%s\' ~/Library/Application\\ Support/Code/User/settings.json')
    while (vscode.running()) {
        delay(1)
        if (vscode.frontmost()) {
            app.doShellScript(
                'grep -q \'"git.autorefresh": false\' ~/Library/Application\\ Support/Code/User/settings.json && ' +
                'sed -e \'s/"git.autorefresh": false/"git.autorefresh": true/\' -i .bak  ~/Library/Application\\ Support/Code/User/settings.json || true')
        } else {
            app.doShellScript(
                'grep -q \'"git.autorefresh": true\' ~/Library/Application\\ Support/Code/User/settings.json && ' +
                'sed -e \'s/"git.autorefresh": true/"git.autorefresh": false/\' -i .bak  ~/Library/Application\\ Support/Code/User/settings.json || true')
        }
    }
}
```

data.title: Python / envFile in launch.json causes issues
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.1 (2648980a697a4c8fb5777dcfb2ab110cec8a2f58, 2017-07-13T19:12:01.887Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.8.0-53-generic
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-docker|Pet|0.0.16
gitignore|cod|0.5.0
githistory|don|0.2.1
python|don|0.6.7
gitlens|eam|4.3.1
vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.2.0
MagicPython|mag|1.0.10
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.1.6
remote-vscode|raf|1.1.0
vscode-icons|rob|7.10.1

(1 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a simple project with a Python launch.json configuration:

`launch.json`
```
{
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [
    {
      "name": "Python",
      "type": "python",
      "request": "launch",
      "stopOnEntry": false,
      "pythonPath": "${config:python.pythonPath}",
      "program": "${file}",
      "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
      "env": {},
      "envFile": "${workspaceRoot}/.env",
      "debugOptions": [
        "WaitOnAbnormalExit",
        "WaitOnNormalExit",
        "RedirectOutput"
      ],
      "console": "integratedTerminal"
    }
  ]
}
```
`script.py`
```
print('This is a test')
```

2. Run the Python debug for script.py

3. The console is set to integratedTerminal as the debug console will otherwise swallow the output. On my own system the output first lists all of the my shell ENV variables, then again iterates them one at a time. It looks like it dies when it hits the LS_COLORS and is interpreting the internal `=` as a split between an environment variable key and value:

```
...
LC_CTYPE=en_CA.UTF-8
SETTING=1
WINDOWID=96468997
zsh: command not found: 34:ln=01
zsh: command not found: 36:mh=00:pi=40
zsh: command not found: 33:so=01
zsh: command not found: 35:do=01
zsh: command not found: 35:bd=40
zsh: command not found: 33
zsh: command not found: 01:cd=40
zsh: command not found: 33
zsh: command not found: 01:or=40
...
```

I have also tried with the shell set to `/bin/bash` with the same result.

Reproduces without extensions: Unable to check as the python extensions are required for the python debug.

Workaround: Removing the .envFile setting from the launch.json profile resolves the issue, or otherwise setting the values in the launch.json .env setting also avoids the problem - so it seems there is some difference in how the .envFile settings are being applied over the ones in .env.

data.title: Content is newer on disk should have overwrite call to action. UX issue
data.body:
I change my theme and I see this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1018196/28381973-5ca64a28-6c71-11e7-879d-d37955199da7.png)

Its already on the compare screen so the CTA is meaningless.

So I click compare and I see the info box.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1018196/28381977-61f34e0e-6c71-11e7-936a-5cc03b779b33.png)

I type "ctrl+s" and go back to compare.

The appropriate call to actions are just present me with "Overwrite, undo, Cancel". 

I searched help for overwrite and it doesn't even exist in edit menu.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1018196/28382061-b085376c-6c71-11e7-92fd-38ba461d4477.png)

My solution was to just close vscode and make the change myself after a restart. That is a terrible work around but it got the job done.

data.title: Find-all-references takes me to the wrong location
emmet in tsx expanding daft things
data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: Win 8.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open TSX file
2. Place cursor end of a `case something:` statement
3. Press tab

So, I had a bit of typescript in my tsx, a case statement, that I wanted to add a comment to the end of, quite reasonable.  So I go the the end of the case, and press TAB to add some indent, and I got...

`case something<:></:>`

Which by any stretch, is undesirable.  I think it needs more intelligence.

Needless to say I had to disable it.
